conclusion: When a point-light is lowered while keeping its horizontal position unchanged, every shadow on the ground moves farther away from its object and becomes longer/larger. The closer the light comes to the ground, the more pronounced both effects are.
Shadow A (shadow of the glove) will slide outward from the glove and stretch, so its overall size increases.
Shadow B (shadow of the small round slab) will also move outward and swell; because the object is flat and low, the change in size is noticeable but modest compared with the others.
Shadow C (shadow of the tall floral figure) will shift the furthest and will lengthen the most, turning into a much longer silhouette of the figure.
Shadow D (shadow of the tape roll) will move outward and grow; its elliptical outline will widen.
Shadow-growth is roughly proportional to the object’s height: C > A > D > B.
All four shadows keep the same general orientation (away from the light), but each one’s footprint travels farther from its object as the light is lowered.
